Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Sinking rates and nutritional quality of organic mater exported from sea ice; the importance of exopolymeric substances
Award.AbstractNarration:
Available data concerning the sinking rates of ice algae are highly divergent, while the characteristics of particles formed from other large organic pools in sea ice have received little study. As an initial step to remedy this situation, funds are provided to study the role of exopolymeric substances (EPS), produced by ice algae, in particle formation. The importance of EPS to particle coagulation and sinking rate is well established for temperate water columns. In sea ice, EPS comprise 20-70% of total particulate organic carbon, but their role in the sinking rate and composition of particles exported from sea ice is poorly understood. Based on previous studies, the PIs predict both positive and negative effects of EPS on particle sinking rate depending on EPS quantity. EPS also is predicted to increase the ratio of carbon to nitrogen (C:N) in the organic matter, which serves as a nutritional indicator.

Based on documented trends in the EPS content of first-year Arctic sea ice, the PIs specifically predict slower sinking rates and higher C:N in particles produced after the export of ice algae, and from the upper levels of the ice column. They also predict slower sinking rates and higher C:N where snow cover is thicker. They will measure the sinking rates of particles released from melted sea-ice cores and test their hypotheses by relating the observed sinking rates to variables such as EPS concentration in the ice. Changes in the contribution of the sea-ice community to different flux periods will be investigated using microscopy and DNA-based molecular techniques. Finally, to help explain the spatial variability in the EPS content of sea ice, they will quantify EPS production rates of cultured ice algae as a function of light level. This work is designed to provide a conceptual framework for understanding and predicting spatial and temporal variability in the sinking rates and nutritional quality of particles released from Arctic sea ice in relation to variables measured in the ice such as: snow depth, chlorophyll, particulate organic carbon, and EPS. The knowledge resulting from this study will contribute to our understanding of the Arctic Ocean carbon cycle and how it may be modified in response to climate variability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Each spring, a bloom of algae develops inside the sea ice overlying the coastal Arctic ocean. These microscopic plants are not accidentally caught inside the ice, instead they actually thrive inside pores and small channels found in the ice, together with a specialized community of other organisms, including bacteria, worms, and crustaceans. The algae increase inside the ice during spring as sunlight returns to the Arctic following the darkness of winter. In late spring, the ice algae, and other material held by the ice, are released into the underlying water column in dramatic pulses that may only last a few days. Such pulses of particles leaving the ice represent a large potential food resource for winter-starved organisms found in the water and sediments underlying the ice. With support from the National Science Foundation, we are trying to understand the role and importance of the ice algae, and other organic matter held by sea ice, for the rest of the Arctic marine ecosystem. During this project, our research group conducted 4 month-long research expeditions between 2011-2014 to study the ice algae found in coastal sea ice near Barrow, Alaska. Using samples collected in Alaska, complemented by experiments and analyses conducted in our home laboratories in New York and Tempe, AZ, we were able to answer several important research questions related to ice algae ecology:

A) Ice algae community composition: When ice algae abundance changes, does the community composition shift as well?

The amount of algae found in the ice in any location is quite variable through time, as well as from one location to another, and between years. Using microscopy to identify which types of algae were present in different samples, we were surprised to find that big changes in algae concentration in the ice were not necessarily connected to changes in which algae were present.

B) Seasonal export of algae from the ice: what controls the timing of the seasonal loss of algae from sea ice?

Algae are typically lost from the ice bottom into the underlying water following melt of the overlying snow cover. It is not immediately obvious why snow melt on top of the ice would affect algae mostly found near the ice bottom. However, thinner snow cover should increase light levels within the ice, to which the algae will respond. We found that ice algae will migrate downwards within the ice, as snow cover becomes thinner and light levels increase. Eventually, they reach the ice-water interface, where they are more likely to be lost to the water below. This interaction between snow melt and algal behavior was not previously appreciated to be part of the loss process.

C) Particle sinking rates following loss: How fast/slow do ice-derived particles sink once released from sea ice?

Once algae and other organic materials are lost from sea ice, they are likely to end up as food for some organism living below the ice. If the particles sink very fast, they are more likely to reach the bottom and be consumed by organisms living in or on the sediments. Meanwhile, slowly sinking particles would probably be consumed by plankton in the water. We found that there are always some fast and some slow sinking particles being released from the ice, but the relative proportion of fast vs slow sinking particles depends on environmental conditions such as snow cover, nutrients available to the ice algae, and the depth of the ice layer from which the particles originate. This research represents a big advance in understanding and predicting sinking rates of material released from sea ice. In turn, the release and sinking of material from sea ice is the main connection between the ecosystem inside the ice and the rest of the Arctic marine food web.
